title: The Black Book of Neoliberal Capitalism: How Capitalism Kills Millions
list-title: The Black Book of Neoliberal Capitalism
subtitle: Applying the logic of 'The Black Book of Communism' to the human cost of capitalism and imperialism
description: Examines the human cost of capitalism, imperialism, and neoliberalism, applying a critical methodology similar to analyses of 'The Black Book of Communism', detailing famines, exploitation, and political interventions.
summary: This article critically examines the human cost of capitalism and neoliberal policies, using a methodology similar to critiques of 'The Black Book of Communism'. It explores historical instances of famine under colonial rule, exploitation in the Congo, and Western-backed political violence in countries like Indonesia and Chile, arguing that the pursuit of profit and power has led to millions of deaths and widespread atrocities.

title: How Rich Countries Keep Poor Countries In Poverty (and Why)
list-title: Neocolonialism: How Rich Countries Keep Poor Countries Poor
subtitle: Neocolonialism, Debt, and the International Institutions Perpetuating Global Inequality
description: Explore how rich countries perpetuate poverty in developing nations through neocolonialism, predatory debt, and structural adjustment policies imposed by institutions like the IMF and World Bank, using historical context and examples like Somalia.
summary: This article details how developed nations maintain control and exploit resources in developing countries through neocolonial practices, leveraging debt and the power of international financial institutions like the IMF and World Bank. It examines the mechanisms of Structural Adjustment Programs (SAPs) and their devastating impact, including a case study of Somalia, arguing that these systems perpetuate inequality and hinder genuine development in the Global South.

title: The Liberalism to Fascism Pipeline: How Economic Systems Shape Society
subtitle: Exploring how economic instability, from post-WWII Keynesianism to modern Neoliberalism, can lead to divisive politics and authoritarian outcomes.
description: Examines the historical and economic link between liberal capitalism (specifically neoliberalism) and the rise of fascistic tendencies, arguing that economic instability under deregulated markets leads to scapegoating marginalized groups instead of addressing systemic issues. Uses examples like Pinochet's Chile and the Reagan-Thatcher era.
summary: An in-depth look at the 'liberalism to fascism pipeline', arguing that the instability and wealth concentration fostered by neoliberal economic policies are often deflected onto marginalized groups, paving the way for authoritarianism. Traces the evolution of economic thought from post-WWII social democracy to neoliberalism and examines its real-world consequences.

title: How Rich Countries Keep Poor Countries in Poverty (And Why)
list-title: How Rich Countries Keep Poor Countries in Poverty
subtitle: Debt, Neoliberalism, and Neocolonial Control
description: Explores how wealthy nations trap developing countries in poverty using neocolonial practices, debt, and institutions like the IMF and World Bank. Details how structural adjustment programs (SAPs) prioritize western interests and resource extraction over local development, using Somalia as an example.
summary: Rich countries exploit developing nations via modern neocolonial methods: debt, international financial institutions (IMF, World Bank), and structural adjustment programs (SAPs). These policies force privatization, trade liberalization, austerity, and resource export, crippling local economies and serving western interests. The case of Somalia shows how this system creates dependency, inequality, and humanitarian crises, keeping resource-rich countries poor while enriching the west.
